msItem.title: Jung-i Kalām-i Ismāʿīlī
جنگ کلام اسماعیلی
msItem.note: This work is an encyclopedic anthology on topics such as the religious sciences, ethics, philosophy, polite learning and the interpretation of dreams, compiled from various texts including Makārim al-akhlāq, Iḥyā ʿulūm al-dīn, Kashf al-niʿma, Rabīʿal-abrār, and Rasā’il ikhwān al-safā’.
Chapter markings disappear after Chapter Four.

The text was compiled for Abū l-Manṣūr Abū l-Naṣr al-Muẓaffar Sultān ‘Abdallāh Quṭb Shāh. On f. 76a it is recorded that the year in which the compiler was ordered to compose the work corresponded with the word intikhāb – i.e. 1054/1644-5.

The following represents a preliminary list of the work's chapters and their place in the manuscript [JW July 2017]:
79a Introduction: on the definition of knowledge.
80b On prayer, repeating the name of God, and using the bathhouse and toothpicks [sic].
89a On which work should be undertaken on which days of the week.
90a On the months of the year.
90b On the effects exerted on the human body by the seasons.
92b On clothing.
93a Chapter Two: on friendship and enmity.
104a Chapter Three: on socializing with people and social conduct.
125a Chapter Four: on clemency, punishment, repentance, and the acceptance of apology.
136a Chapter on patience? Heading blank.
145a Chapter on justice? Heading blank
167b Section – anecdotes on fools who were Arabs. Chapter unmarked.
171a On intelligent fools.
172b On praiseworthy things accomplished by intelligent men.
175b On praise and blame.
219a Chapter (marked) on the foundation of Islam and belief.
229a On animal and plant life.
230a On impure things (masūkhāt).
237a On the stratagems (ḥiyalhā) exhibited by some famous figures.
245a On dreams and their interpretation.
252b Main text ends.
1a ‘Supplement’, described as a separate epistle in reality, devoted to five words connected to kingship. Consists of five chapters and a conclusion.
1a Introduction: on the meaning of the word ‘king’.
12b Chapter Two: on the king’s counsel and judgement.
27a Chapter Three: on seriousness (jidd) and the exertion of effort (jahd).
38a Chapter Four: on the ordering of retainers and servants.
50a On the customs and behavior of kings
The first page of volume 2 is missing.

foliation.p: The beginning of the work is intact, but the foliation begins at f. 77. Main text foliated f.77-f.252, followed by 'Supplement' foliated f. 1-f.76.

layout.p: 1 column throughout. 17 lines. Impression left by hand guide.

handNote.desc: Copied in black ink in Nasta’liq script. Emendations in a different hand. Some chapter headings, Arabic text and titles marked in red ink.

list.item: f. 77a Stamps: dated Ramadan 1237, 1244. Inscription dated 1262

bindingDesc.p: Red and brown leather on pasteboard. Mislabelled as Jung-i Kalām-i Shiʿr on spine.

provenance.p: From the collection of Colonel George William Hamilton (1807-1868) who served in India from 1823 to 1867 latterly as Commissioner in Delhi. He acquired over a thousand Indian and Persian manuscripts of which 352 were selected after his death for the British Museum. The remainder were purchased in 1868 by Alexander Lindsay, 25th Earl of Crawford.

acquisition.p: Purchased by Mrs Enriqueta Rylands, on behalf of the John Rylands Library, in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford.

source.p: Bibliographical description based on an index created by Reza Navabpour circa 1993. Identification of provenance based on manuscript catalogue by Michael Kerney, circa 1890s. Revised and expanded by James White with reference to the manuscript 2017.

availability.p: The mansucript is available for consultation by any accredited reader, see Becoming a Reader for details. Please contact uml.special-collections@manchester.ac.uk for further information on the availability of this manuscript.
